loans.use: to buy fertilizer and poison to prepare the land

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.en:
Hello! Meet Magdalena, a hard-working, very honest and warm-hearted farmer who hails from the Kericho area of Kenya, which has one of the best weather patterns on Earth that favors farming.

Magdalena’s upbringing was very challenging and, because of this, she promised herself that she would work hard and get out of poverty. That is why she started farming 10 years ago. Through farming, she has been able to earn a decent income. Magdalena is the breadwinner in her family, and this really pushes her to work hard so that her family will have a bright future and also so her parents will have a comfortable life.

Magdalena is seeking a loan to start horticultural farming so that she can use the excess space on her land. She dreams of buying more land and increasing her horticulture business. Accessing funds is very difficult for a woman in Africa, but through institutions such as Juhudi Kilimo and Kiva, Magdalena is optimistic that her dream will be realized and her life will completely change.

Through the income from horticultural farming, Magdalena will assure her children of a bright future, and she will be able to pay tuition fees for her siblings who depend on her. Through your loan the promise of supporting small scale farmers will be achieved.

loans.use: to start horticultural farming.

loans.name: Vestine

texts.en:
Vestine is 45 years old and married with seven children aged between 4 and 20 years, all of whom go to school. She is a farmer and has been growing rice for the past 19 years.

With the loan from Kiva, Vestine would like to buy fertilizer for rice. The profits from the business will be used to renovate her house and pay school fees for her children.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for rice.

loans.name: Consolee

texts.en:
Consolee is 31 years old. She is married, with four children, ages between 2 and 10 years.  Three of them go to school. 

Consolee is a farmer, and she has been growing rice for the past 12 years. With the loan from Kiva, she would like to buy more fertilizers for rice. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees for her children.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers for rice.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more bags of water to resell to her clients

loans.name: Jose Julio

texts.es:
Julio, de 52 años de edad, estudio hasta quinto grado, está soltero y no tiene hijos.

Julio, es agricultor desde que era muy pequeño, lo que aprendió de su padre, porque siempre lo llevaba a trabajar al salir de la escuela, pero después dejo la escuela y se dedicó solo a trabajar y desde entonces, trabaja en la agricultura año tras año.

El préstamo lo necesita para preparar la tierra, ya que se acerca la época agrícola y debe tener listo el  terreno para cuando comience el invierno.

Él sueña con incrementar los cultivos y obtener mejores cosechas.
texts.en:
Julio, 52 years old, studied up to fifth grade, he is single and has no children.

Julio is a farmer since he was very young. He learned from his father, who always took him to work after picking him up from school. Then, he left school and devoted himself to his work. Since that moment, he has worked in agriculture year after year.

He needs the loan to prepare the soil, since the harvest season is getting close and he must have it ready before winter starts.

He wishes to expand the fields and hopes the crops yield better product.

loans.use: to prepare the soil, since the harvest season is getting close and he must have it ready before winter starts.

loans.name: Juana Corina

texts.es:
Juana, de 57 años de edad, esta soltera, estudio hasta segundo grado, tiene cinco hijos, pero ninguno depende de ella.

Juana, se dedica  al comercio de verduras y frutas de época.

Ella necesita el dinero para comprar sacos de tamarindo y de otras frutas, para venderlos.

Juana, sueña con enseñarles a trabajar a su familia, para que sepan algún oficio o trabajo.
texts.en:
Juana, 57 years old, is single and studied until the fourth grade.  She has five children, but none of them are dependent on her.

She dedicates herself to the business of vegetables and fruits in season.

She needs the loan to purchase bags of tamarind and other fruits to sell.

Juana dreams of teaching her family to work, so that they know a trade or business.

loans.use: to buy bags of tamarind and other fruits to sell.

loans.name: Martine

texts.en:
Martine is 25 years old. She is married with three children aged between 1 and 6 years; they all go to school. She is a farmer and she has been farming for the past six years. With the loan from Kiva, she would like to buy fertilizer for rice. The profits from the business will be used to buy food for home consumption. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for rice.

loans.name: Jacha Uru Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “JACHA URU” iniciará el décimo quinto ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Alto Lima, está compuesta por nueve  integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Fanny es la Tesorera. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: servicio de seguridad, tienda de barrio, venta de ropa, venta de chuño (papa deshidratada), venta de comida, venta de CD’s, venta de carne de pollo.

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Fanny es integrante, ella indica que hace cuatro años que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por la invitación de una amiga que es cliente de la institución. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de venta de CD’s; da a conocer que este negocio lo implementó hace varios años, aprendiendo la comercialización de estos productos al trabajar con su tía, es por esta razón que con el pasar del tiempo y con el ahorro de un capital decide implementar su negocio independiente.
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de CD’s por mayor) que adquirirá de las vendedoras mayoristas ciudad de La Paz y posteriormente lo comercializará en su espacio de venta. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar a su familia económicamente, ya que ella es soltera.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta el crédito y las capacitaciones que ofrece la institución.

En la imagen se puede identificar a el asesor que acompaña al grupo, él esta vestido con una chompa ploma.
texts.en:
The "JACHA URU” credit association is starting its fifteenth cycle with Pro Mujer as part of the Centro Focal de Alto Lima. It is composed of 9 members and is directed by a board of directors of which Fanny is the Treasurer. The businesses that the members of the association run are varied and include: security services, a corner shop, a clothes-selling business, a chuño-selling business (freeze-dried potato product), a food-selling business, a CD-selling business and a chicken meat-selling business. 

The loan they are taking out will benefit small micro-entrepreneurs such as Fanny. She joined Pro Mujer 4 years ago, joining at the invitation of a friend who is a client of the institution. She currently has a business selling CDs. She set this business up some years ago, having learned how to sell these products through working with her aunt. As time went by and she saved up capital, she decided to set up her own independent business. 

The loan that she is now taking out will be used to increase her working capital (by buying CDs in bulk) which she will get from the wholesale vendors in the city of La Paz and will then sell at her stall. This type of work allows her to generate the resources to support her family economically, as she is single.   

When asked what she liked about Pro Mujer, she responded that she likes the loans and the training that the institution offers. 

In the image the group's consultant can also be seen. He is dressed in a gray jersey.

loans.use: to buy CDs in bulk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase an overstitch sewing machine to sew collars to make her work more efective and improve her income for the welfare of her family.

loans.name: Delphine

texts.en:
Delphine is 43 years old and married with five children aged between 3 and 15 years, all of whom go to school. She is a farmer and has been growing rice for the past 21 years. With the loan from Kiva, she would like to buy more fertilizer for rice. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees for her children.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizer for rice.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy land

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy dresses, skirts, and aprons to sell.

loans.name: Memunatu's Group

texts.en:
Malia is a 65-year-old hardworking woman from Jekarayili in the Northern region of Ghana.  She is married and has eight children. (Malia is the individual pictured with her hand on the paddy rice, with a white veil on.)

Malia is a member of a parboiled rice processing group that has been in business for the last 40 years. The name of the group is ‘Wuni Tira - Jekarayili’. She earns a good profit from the business simply because the group has been trained by Grameen Ghana on how to process high quality parboiled rice for the Ghanaian market.

Malia and ‘Wuni Tira - Jekarayili’ group have asked for a loan of GHS 5,100.  Malia’s share of the loan is GHS 300, which she will use to buy paddy rice from rice farmers for processing. 

Malia is adding more value to her product and earning more income to repay this loan and support her family with food, health care and school fees.
She thanks Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To buy paddy rice from rice farmers for processing.

loans.name: Azniv

texts.en:
Azniv is a devoted and skilled farmer from Burastan village. She lives together with her husband, son, and daughter-in-law. 

In greenhouses located near their house, Azniv cultivates tomato and greens.  She sells the gathered harvest in local markets with the help of her husband. 

All the income earned from the farming business is used for the family's daily expenses, so little money is left for investing on the farm.  Azniv asks this loan to purchase supplies for renovating her greenhouses (wire, polyethylene cover) and for pesticides and fertilizer to enlarge crop production. 

As this is Azniv's first loan, it has been approved within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and SEF. The first-chance loan program provides loans to people who did not have access to credit products before because they have no credit history.

loans.use: to pay for supplies for renovating her greenhouses and for pesticides and fertilizer to enlarge crop production

loans.name: Mujeres Positivas Group

texts.es: Gliceria de 55 años, integrante del grupo “Mujeres Positivas” con 06 integrantes emprendedoras y responsables, todas ellas vecinas de la zona. Gliceria se dedica a la venta de abarrotes, lleva más de 9 años en esta actividad. Solicitó el crédito para la compra de arroz, aceite, azúcar.Seguir implementando su negocio es su mayor deseo. Gliceria de 55 años es casada con 03 hijos. El grupo “Mujeres Positivas” agradece a las personas que hicieron posible éste crédito. Gliceria se encuentra sentada es la segunda del lado izquierdo viste blusa blanca y falda ploma.
texts.en:
Gliceria, 55, is married and has three children.  She's one of six enterprising and responsible members of Mujeres Positivas Group, all of them neighbors in the area.

Gliceria earns a living selling groceries.  She has been in this line of work for more than nine years.  Her biggest desire is to continue carrying out her business.

She requested the loan to buy rice, oil, and sugar.

Mujeres Positivas Group is grateful to the people who made this loan possible.  Gliceria's the second person from the left; she's seated and is wearing a white blouse and gray skirt.

loans.use: to buy rice, oil, and sugar

loans.name: Manushak

texts.en: Manushak is the mother of two daughters and lives with her family in Vostan village. Her elder daughter is a student in Yerevan State University and Manushak works hard to manage to cover the family's needs and at the same time save money for her daughter's education. Because Mariam's education is the first priority for Manushak, she works day and night. Manushak asks lenders to support her in covering her daughter's university tuition. This is her first cooperation with Kiva and she hopes to receive lenders' support.

loans.use: to pay for her daughter Mariam's university tuition

loans.name: Mario

texts.es:
Mario es un hombre de 43 años de edad, vive con su pareja, tiene un hijo de 12 años, y su negocio es un taller de muellería.
Él es buen padre, emprendedor, constante, paciente, responsable y trabajador. su negocio lo desarrolla en la zona ‘16 de julio’ un área caracterizada por la producción manufacturera y por su feria los días jueves y domingos, donde se puede encontrar desde una aguja para coser ropa hasta un tractor para sembrar la tierra. De clima frío (4-12 grados centígrados) y rayos solares muy fuertes que pueden quemar la piel, a una altura promedio de 3800 metros sobre el nivel del mar.
Mario es de tez morena, cabello negro corto, ojos pardos, baja estatura, complexión física mediana, su lengua nativa es el Aymará que se habla en el lugar y habla español por cultura general y por el negocio que realiza. Su vida la comparte con su esposa que trabaja y con su hijo que estudia en la escuela, viven en un cuarto alquilado construida de ladrillo y cemento con techo de calamina que cuenta con agua potable gas domiciliario, alcantarillado y energía eléctrica. Su negocio es un taller de muellería; los muelles son parte de la suspensión de todo vehículo, se encargan de soportar el peso de la carga y además de mantener los ejes centrados. Los trabajos que realiza son: recargado de cremalleras hidráulicas, engrasado de rodamientos, colocado tacos de aluminio, vaciado de catalizadores y otros. Actividad que realiza de lunes a sábado en horarios del día en un cuarto habilitado como taller cercano a su domicilio. “trabajo en talleres mecánicos desde muy joven, realicé diferentes actividades hasta que me independicé, ahora cuento con mi taller el cual administro…” comenta. La ventaja de su negocio es la experiencia que tiene, la desventaja es la falta de material con el cual trabajar. Su sueño es ampliar su taller y brindar otros servicios como llantería y mecánica, él desea realizar la compra de por mayor de muelles y otros materiales de trabajo para su taller. Esta es la 1 secuencia de préstamos con la institución en 4 años que trabaja de forma independiente. 
Es por esos motivos que Mario solicita un préstamo para la compra de muelles para contar con material de trabajo para su taller mecánico.
texts.en:
Mario is a man of 43 years of age.  He lives with his partner and has a 12 years old son.  His business is a springs workshop.

He is a good father, entrepreneur, steady, patient, responsible and hardworking.  He developed his business in the "16 de julio" zone, an area characterized by manufacturing output and its fair on Thursdays and Sundays, where you can find anything from a needle to sew clothes to a tractor to sow the land. Its cold (4-12 degrees Celsius) weather and very strong solar rays can burn skin, at an average altitude of 3,800 meters above sea level.

Mario has a dark complexion, short black hair, brown eyes, short, and medium physique. His native Aymara language is spoken in this place and generally speaking, Spanish by culture and in the business you do. His life he shares with his wife who works and with his son studying in school.  They live in a rented room, which is built of brick, cement and a tin roof.  The house has water, gas, sewage, and electricity.

His business is a springs workshop; the springs are part of the suspension of a vehicle, they are responsible for supporting the weight of the load and also to keep the axes centered. Typical jobs of this work are recharged hydraulic zippers, greased bearings, placing aluminum studs, emptying catalysts and others.  The activity is performed Monday through Saturday during work hours in a room fitted out as a workshop near his home. "I have worked in garages since I was very young, I did different activities until I went solo, I now have my workshop which I manage ..." he says.

The advantage of his business is the experience he has, the disadvantage is the lack of material with which to work. His dream is to expand his shop and provide other services such as tire repair and mechanics.  He wants to purchase springs by wholesale and other work materials for his workshop.  This is the 1st sequence of loans with the institution in which he has four years working independently.

It is for these reasons that Mario is requesting a loan to purchase springs to have working material for his garage.

loans.use: to purchase springs in order to have working material for his workshop.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more fertilizers for maize.

loans.name: Angelique

texts.en:
Angelique is aged 43 years old. She is married with six children between 3 and 18 years old, four of whom go to school. She is a farmer and she has been growing rice for the past 21 years, while her husband is a businessman. With the loan from Kiva, she would like to pay workers who grow rice. The profits from the business will be used to pay the school fees of her children and to improve her savings.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To pay workers who grow rice.

loans.name: Dative

texts.en:
Dative is 35 years old and is married with four children aged between 3 and 13 years, all of whom go to school. She is a farmer and has been growing rice for the past 19 years. With the loan from Kiva, she would like to buy fertilizer for rice. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees for her children.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for rice.

loans.name: Lilit

texts.en:
The sunny woman in the photo is Lilit from Musaler village of the Ejmiatsin region. She lives there with her husband and two sons.

Lilit is skilled and devoted to her work as a farmer, and manages agriculture well. Specifically, she keeps seven calves and cultivates corn seeds. Lilit's farm is not very rich and the income from it is not big, but due to Lilit's care and hard work it brings income for her family. She is asking for this loan to purchase six oxen, two mother pigs and forage for feeding the livestock.

Because this is Lilit's first loan, it has been approved within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and SEF. The first-chance loan program provides loans to people who did not have access to credit products before because they have no credit history.

loans.use: to pay for six oxen, two mother pigs and forage for feeding the livestock to enlarge the farm and gather more income for her family's living.

loans.name: María Candelaria

texts.es:
Candelaria, de 63 años de edad, estudio hasta tercer grado, debido a la situación económica que en ese entonces atravesaba su familia, no pudo continuar estudiando, tiene 3 hijos, pero todo ya formaron sus propias familias.

Candelaria, se dedica a la venta de tortillas y desde hace 5 años decidio colocar un comedor, negocio que tiene ubicado en su casa, el horario que tiene para la atención a los clientes es de 6.30 a.m. a 7:00 de la noche.

El crédito será utilizado para comprar una plancha para hacer pupusas y además comprara sodas para vender.

El sueño Candelaria, es continuar con su comedor y que este sea rentable y sostenible por mucho tiempo.
texts.en:
Candelaria is 63 years old and studied through the third grade. Due to her family’s financial situation, she was not able to continue her studies. She has three children, all of whom have started their own families.

Candelaria sells tortillas. Five years ago, she decided to set up a dining area. Her business is located in her home. She serves customers between the hours of 6:30 A.M. and 7:00 P.M. This loan will be used to buy a griddle for making “pupusas” [stuffed tortillas]. She will also buy sodas to sell.

Candelaria dreams of continuing to manage her diner so that it remains profitable and sustainable for a long time.

loans.use: to acquire a griddle for making "pupusas" and to buy sodas to sell.

loans.name: Bekim

texts.en:
Bekim is 43 years old, married and the father of three children. He is hardworking and does a lot in order to support his family, working all day long and never taking a day off. He works in construction and also is involved in agriculture, planting corn and wheat for family use and to sell for a profit. Although he works hard, he loves what he does and enjoys his work and being able to provide for his family.

For the first time Bekim is requesting a loan so that he can purchase a tractor. His current one is damaged and very worn from years of hard work. He hopes that a new tractor will not only allow him to continue his business but also make it better, being more effective and efficient in his work. His goal is to eventually open a private construction company. He promises to pay on time and is grateful to all of the lenders.

loans.use: to purchase a tractor

loans.name: Graciela

texts.es:
Graciela es una mujer de 28 años de edad, soltera, tiene 4 hijos de 10, 6, 4 y 2 años, y su negocio es el comercio de Quinua.
Ella es buena madre, buena oyente, comprensiva, paciente, responsable y trabajadora. Su negocio lo desarrolla en la comunidad de ‘Batallas’ un área rural caracterizada por encontrarse en cercanías al lago sagrado Titicaca. Los pobladores trabajan en agricultura, ganadería y pesca. De clima frío y seco con una temperatura que varía durante el día entre 0 – 142 grados centígrados.
Graciela es de tez morena, cabello negro largo lo usa trenzado, ojos pardos, baja estatura, complexión física delgada, su forma de vestir es tradicional (sombrero, manta y pollera), su lengua nativa es el Aymará que se habla en el lugar y habla español por cultura general y por el comercio que efectúa. Su vida la realiza en compañía de sus hijos; los 2 mayores estudian en la escuela, los menores aún no se encuentran en edad escolar. Viven en una casa propia construida de ladrillo y cemento con techo de calamina y cuenta con energía eléctrica, alcantarillado y agua proveniente de vertiente. Su negocio es el comercio de quinua, ella produce en sus tierras el producto, y también compra de otros productores para realizar ventas por mayor. “la venta de quinua es un mercado inestable porque abunda en los meses de marzo a mayo (época de cosecha), y escasea en agosto y octubre, ya que los agricultores guardan la quinua hasta estar seguros de su próxima cosecha…”, comenta. La ventaja de su negocio es que ella produce en sus tierras el producto, la desventaja es la poca producción en cambio de temporada. Su sueño es contar con quinua a la venta durante todo el año, ella desea realizar la compra de chuño y papa para vender en época de poca producción de quinua. Esta es la 1 secuencia de préstamo con la institución en 6 años que desarrolla esta actividad.
Es por esos motivos que Graciela solicita un préstamo para la compra de chuño y papa para vender en época de poca producción de quinua.
texts.en:
Graciela is a 28-year-old woman who is single and has four children (ages 10, 6, 4, and 2). Her business involves selling quinoa. Graciela is a wonderful mother who is understanding, patient, responsible, hardworking, and a good listener. She conducts her business in the community of Batallas, a rural area that is near the sacred Lake Titicaca. The residents work in agriculture, livestock breeding, and fishing. The weather is cold and dry, with a temperature that varies throughout the day between 0-14 degrees Celsius.

Graciela has a dark complexion, long black braided hair, brown eyes, a short stature, and a thin physique. She wears traditional apparel (hat, shawl, and skirt). Her native language is Aymará, which she speaks in her town, but she also speaks Spanish as part of the general culture and to carry out her business. She shares her life with her children. The two oldest attend school, while the younger ones are not of school age. They live in a brick and cement house with a metal sheet roof. Their home receives electricity, sewage services, and water that comes from a spring.

Graciela’s business is selling quinoa that is produced on her land. She also buys from other producers so that she can generate more sales. “Selling quinoa is an unstable market because it is abundant in the months of March through May (the harvesting season), but is scarce in August through October. Farmers store quinoa as a safety net until the next harvest,” says Graciela. The advantage of her business is she is able to produce on her own land, while the disadvantage is the low production that occurs at the change of season. Her dream is to have quinoa to sell throughout the year. Graciela also wants to buy “chuños” [dried potatoes] and regular potatoes to sell during the time when quinoa production is low. This is her first loan cycle with Emprender. Graciela has been in this business for six years.

For the reasons previously stated, Graciela is requesting a loan in order to buy “chuños” and regular potatoes to sell during the quinoa low season.

loans.use: to buy “chuños” [dried potatoes] and regular potatoes to sell during the season when quinoa production is low.

loans.name: Las Yungueñitas Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “LAS YUNGUEÑITAS” iniciará el quinto ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Juan Pablo II, está compuesta por ocho  integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Carmen es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: venta de accesorios de autopartes, venta de mantas,  venta de bolsas de construcción, venta de calzados deportivos, venta de verduras, venta de juguetes, venta de prendas de vestir.

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Carmen es integrante, ella indica que hace once años que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por la invitación de su madre que es cliente de la institución. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de venta de calzados deportivos; da a conocer que este negocio lo implementó hace varios años, con el primer préstamo obtenido por Pro Mujer y con la ayuda de sus padres quienes le dieron un espacio de venta donde comercializar sus productos.
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de calzados deportivos por mayor) que adquirirá de las vendedoras mayoristas ciudad de La Paz y posteriormente lo comercializará en su espacio de venta. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar a su familia económicamente, ya que ella es casada y tienes un hijo.  
Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta el crédito y las capacitaciones que ofrece la institución.
texts.en:
The "Las Yungueñitas" communal bank will start its fifth cycle with Pro Mujer as part of the Juan Pablo II regional office. It is made up of eight members and it is directed by a board, of which Carmen is the president. The communal bank's members are moving forward with a variety of businesses. Among them are selling auto parts and accessories, selling blankets, selling construction bags, selling sports footwear, selling vegetables, selling toys, and selling clothing.

The loan they will take out will benefit small microbusinesswomen like Carmen. She indicates that she joined Pro Mujer eleven years ago at the invitation of her mother, who is a customer of the institution. Currently she has a business selling sports footwear. She makes it known that she started this business several years ago with the first loan obtained through Pro Mujer and with the help of her parents, who gave her a sales space where she could sell her product.

The loan she will now take out is to increase capital (to buy wholesale sports footwear) that she will acquire from the wholesale vendors in the city of La Paz. She will then sell it at her sales space. This form of work allows her to generate resources to support her family economically, since she is married and has a son.

When she is asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she responds that she likes the loan and the trainings the institutions offers.

loans.use: to buy wholesale sports footwear

loans.name: Sidi

texts.en:
Sidi is a married woman. She has three children. She describes herself to be ambitious. She operates a retail business where she sells omena (a small type of fish). She has been involved in this business for three years. Her business is located in an area with potential, and her primary customers are locals. 

She will use the 40,000 KES loan to buy more stock of fish for resale. Her business goal is to have a big shop within five years. This is her second loan with SMEP Microfinance bank. Her previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more stock of fish for resale.

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
Patriciah is a 55-year-old mother from Vihiga County, which is located in the western part of Kenya. She is a widow, she supports four people in the family and she has four children, ages 27, 20, 17 and ten years old.

She has a retail shop, which she has been operating for the past four years, and makes a monthly income of 9,000 KES. She is taking her fifth loan with VisionFund Kenya, which she will use to purchase sugar, cooking oil, maize flour and soap for resale. She will use the anticipated profit to increase her stock of goods.

Her dream is to educate her children and increase her stock of goods.

loans.use: to purchase sugar, cooking oil, maize flour and soap for resale.

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.en:
Jacqueline is 38 years of age. She is married with four children between the ages of one and 18 years old. Two of them go to school. She is a farmer and she has been growing maize for the past 18 years. Her husband is a farmer also. 

With the loan from Kiva, she would like to pay workers who harvested maize. The profits from the business will be used to buy a cow for rearing.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to pay workers who harvested maize.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is a Kiva borrower. She has two children. She describes herself to be committed. 

She operates a beauty salon where she offers beauty services. She has been involved in this business for eight years. Her primary customers are ladies. She will use the 80,000 KES loan to buy salon equipment. Her business goal is to have increased profits within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will be independent. 

This is her fifth loan with SMEP Microfinance bank. Her previous loan was repaid successfully. She will use the anticipated profits to educate her children.

loans.use: to buy salon equipment.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Hello lenders, meet Mary. She is a hardworking smallholder farmer based in the Kapsowar area of Kenya. She has been doing farming on her one acre plot of land for more than a decade. She keeps a dairy cow and chickens for eggs. The trees planted on the land shows how Mary is environmentally responsible. This 40-year-old farmer is also a mother. 

Mary is seeking a loan to purchase grains. For extra income, she buys and sells cereals. The only way she can expand this business is by getting her hands on more grains from the farmers. To do this, she has to leverage her business and pay the debt using the returns she will get from selling the cereals. 

Mary describes her childhood as difficult. It took hard work and street smarts to get where she is today. The environment she has been exposed to has made her very cautious when approaching new business opportunities. The fact that she is somewhat risk-averse makes her a favorable borrower with a sober approach on how she is going to spend and regain money. 

She stated that she will use the increased income to pay for her children's education.

loans.use: to purchase cereals.

loans.name: Poline

texts.en:
Poline is 31 years old. She is married with three children aged between 2 and 10 years old, one of whom goes to school. She is a farmer and she has been growing rice for the past 11 years, while her husband is a businessman. With the loan from Kiva, she would like to pay workers who grow rice. The profits from the business will be used to improve her family's welfare.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain under served by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To pay workers who grow rice.

loans.name: Augustin

texts.en:
Augustin is 47 years old. He is married with 6 children, aged between 4 and 24 years. All of his children go to school. He is a farmer, and he has been growing rice for the past 23 years. His wife is a farmer as well. 

With his loan from Kiva lenders, Augustin would like to pay for the labor to cultivate his rice fields. The profits from the business will be used to renovate his house.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. 

For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to pay for the labor to cultivate rice.

loans.name: Celso

texts.en:
Celso is a mason. He is 37 years old and he lives at his father's house. Celso is a father of two daughters; they are going to school. Celso is divorced.

Celso needs a loan to buy new tools because he plans to start his own construction company. Celso loves his daughters a lot and he will give his best to support them. He hopes you can help him because his ex-wife is currently unemployed.

Celso is in the picture at the place where he lives, and you can see some of the materials he uses to work.

loans.use: to buy new tools

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy staples including palm oil for resale

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta is from Gay village of the Armavir region. She lives with her husband and son and is involved in the farming business together with them. They cultivate cabbage, tomatoes and greens and sell the gathered harvest in the local market. All the available income is used for survival and nothing remains to invest in the farming business. So Julieta is asking for this loan to purchase a polyethylene cover and wires for the greenhouse to develop the farming business and get a higher income for the family.

As this is her first loan, it has been approved within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and SEF. The first-chance loan program provides loans to people who did not have access to credit products before because they have no credit history.

loans.use: to pay for a polyethylene cover and wires for the greenhouse to develop her farming business and get a higher income for the family.

loans.name: San Simon Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “SAN SIMON” iniciará el primer ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Panamericana, está compuesta por ocho  integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Nieves es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: venta de carne, servicio de construcción, venta de comida, venta de pescado, tienda de barrio. 

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Nieves es integrante, ella indica que es la primera vez que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por la invitación de una amiga que es cliente de la institución. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de venta de comida; da a conocer que este negocio lo inicio hace varios años, con un pequeño capital para emprender su negocio, menciona que este negocio lo aprendió de su madre que tenía un negocio similar. 

El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra arroz y carne por mayor) que adquirirá de las vendedoras de la ciudad de El Alto y posteriormente a la elaboración, lo comercializará en su espacio de venta. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar a su familia económicamente, ya que ella es soltera y tiene dos hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta la capacitación que ofrece la institución.
texts.en:
The “SAN SIMON” communal bank will be starting its first loan cycle with Pro Mujer, as part of the Panamericana regional center. The group is made up of eight members, and it is led by a governing board, with Nieves as President. The businesses operated by the communal bank members are diverse, including meat sales, construction services, food sales, fish sales, and a neighborhood store. 

The loan they will receive will benefit small microentrepreneurs such as the member Nieves. She note that this is her first time getting involved with Pro Mujer. She joined it on the invitation of a friend who is a client of the institution. Currently, Nieves has a business selling food. She says that she started this business several years ago, with a little bit of capital to set up her business. She mentions that she learned this work from her mother, who had a similar business. 

The loan that she will now take out is aimed at increasing her capital, to buy rice and meat on a wholesale basis. She will purchase these items from sellers in the city of El Alto, and after she prepares them, she will sell them from her sales stand. This method of working allows her to generate resources to support her family economically, since she is single and has two children. 

When she is asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she responds that she likes the training offered by the institution.

loans.use: to buy rice and meat on a wholesale basis.

loans.name: Ana Azucena

texts.es:
Ana, de 21 años de edad, estudio hasta bachillerato, no continúo sus estudios por motivos económicos, es madre soltera y tiene dos niñas gemelas de 2 años de edad.- Ana, vive con su papá y dos hermanas menores que están estudiando en la escuela de la comunidad.
 
Actualmente Ana, trabaja como dependiente en una tienda, en el caserío donde vive a 25 metros de su casa, anteriormente tuvo una pequeña granja de pollos de engorde, ahora además de su trabajo compra y vende cerdos y su papa le ayuda.

Ana, utilizara el crédito para comprar 2 cerdos para engordarlos y venderlos, ya que su papá tiene experiencia en esta actividad y él le está apoyando con ello.

Su sueño es, tener una granja de cerdos y agradece a kiva por apoyarle, para empezar a hacer realidad su sueño.
texts.en:
Ana is 21, studied high school and didn’t continue due to financial reasons.  She is a single mom and has two-year-old twin daughters.  Ana lives with her dad and two younger sisters that are in the community school.

Currently Ana works independently at a store, in the neighborhood that is 25 meters from her house.  She previously had a small chicken farm, now she also buys and sells pigs and her dad helps her.

Ana will use the loan to buy two pigs to feed them and sell them when grown, her dad has experience in this activity and is supporting her with it.

Her dream is to have a pig farm and is grateful to Kiva for the support to start making her dream come true.

loans.use: to buy two pigs, feed them and sell them when grown.

loans.name: Destiny Group

texts.en:
Martin is the group representative of Destiny group from Mankessim in the Nfantsiman District of the Central Region of Ghana. He is a 40-year-old trader who is married with 3 children, and all the children are currently in school. The eldest child is 8 years old and the youngest is 3 years old.

Martin sells herbal medicines and has been in this business for the past 5 years, so he has gained much experience.  He has 2 branches of his business in different locations. Martin has two employees who he pays on a monthly basis.

Martin is also into farming to support the family and as an additional source of income.  He has a vision to own at least 6  branches of his business in the future due to increasing demand for herbal medicine in the communities.

Martin and his group members have been clients of the field partner since 2009 with on-time repayment records. Martin is requesting a micro loan to support him in increasing his stock levels to meet the demand from his customers.

Martin will use the profit from the business to support his future expansion plans and the remaining to support his family. Martin is grateful to all his micro lenders for their generous support.

loans.use: to buy local medicines for resale

loans.name: Ewuradze Na Aye Group

texts.en:
Ama is a 53-year-old woman who is a native of Twifo Praso in the Central Region of Ghana. She is divorced with 6 children to cater for and their ages are  between 14 and 31 years. Two of the children are attending school.

Ama is a food vendor who prepares a variety of dishes such as fufu (dumpling) and soup, banku (corn dough) and stew, and rice balls and soup. She has been in this business for 20 years now. She has been a client of the field partner since 2008 to grow her business to the current level through micro loan support.

Ama had been committed to her repayment obligations with all her previous loans.  She has 10 employees who assist her in the smooth running of the bar. Many customers prefer to patronise her bar for food due to her good customer service, so there is a high demand for her services.

She needs additional working capital support to buy meat, fish and other ingredients to prepare more food to meet her customers' demands. The income from the sale of the food will help support her and the children as a single mother. Ama thanks all her micro lenders for their support in meeting her business needs.

loans.use: to buy meat, fish, tinned tomatoes, cassava, groundnut and spices

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a boat because he rents his current one

loans.name: Olga

texts.en: Olga is single and has three sons, but only one lives with her. She has owned a laundry for more than 15 years and says that thanks to her work, she has been able to support her family. She would like to grow her business and open another branch. She is asking for a loan to buy some supplies for her laundry, such as hangers and plastic bags.

loans.use: to buy hangers and plastic bags for her laundry.

loans.name: María Julia

texts.es:
María de 65 años de edad, logró cursar hasta 2º grado, no pudo seguir debido a la situación económica de su familia, todos sus hijos son mayores y han formado sus propios hogares.

María se ha dedicado a trabajar desde muy pequeña, luego acompañó pero su pareja la abandonó y tuvo que trabajar sola para mantener a sus hijos, actualmente tiene una tortillería en la cual se le ayuda una hija, comienzan desde muy temprano a preparar los materiales para terminar a las 7:00 AM porque sus clientes llegan desde muy temprano a comprar, además María vende pescado fresco trabajo que aprendió de su madre.

Ella solicita este crédito para comprar maíz para la elaboración de tortillas y para comprar una cocina.

Ella espera seguir trabajando y seguir teniendo el apoyo de su hija.
texts.en:
María, 65 years old, was able to study through 2nd grade. She could not continue due to her family's economic situation. All of her children are adults and have formed their own households.

María has been working since she was very young. Then she was in a relationship, but her partner left her and she had to work alone in order to support her children. Currently she has a tortilla shop, in which one of her daughters helps her. They start very early to prepare the materials in order to finish at 7:00 AM because her customers arrive starting very early to buy. María also sells fresh fish, work she learned from her mother.

She is asking for this loan in order to buy corn to make tortillas and to buy a stove.

She hopes to continue working and to continue to have the support of her daughter.

loans.use: to buy corn to make tortillas and to buy a stove

loans.name: Good Work Group

texts.en:
Yunis is in her early 40's and is married with 4 children, one of whom is in school while the other 3 are now grown. 

Yunis has been selling chips with meat balls, chicken, and eggs for 3 years. She also has a shop where she sells cosmetics. She works daily from 10am to midnight and is able to make a fair monthly profit.

This will be Yunis's 5th loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to buy Irish potatoes, cooking oil, meat, chicken, eggs, charcoal for cooking, as well as more cosmetics. She has repaid all her loans successfully. She used the profits to both pay school fees, shop rent, and loan repayments, as well as cover her household expenses.  

Yunis will use this current loan to open a grocery store and buy drinks for Easter weekend. She dreams of traveling outside the country to buy clothes and open a clothing shop. 

Yunis will share this loan with her loan group "Good Work" which consists of 6 members who will hold each other accountable for repaying the loan.

loans.use: to open a grocery store and buy drinks for Easter weekend.

loans.name: Michelle

texts.en:
Michelle raises and sells goat and native chickens to earn a living. This is the source of her income. She is a 37-year-old married woman with three dependents, ages 14,13 and 4 years old.  Her husband works as a technician in a private company, which helps her to meet their daily needs. She lives in Talibon, Bohol. 

In order to continue to operate her business, Michelle has requested a loan to buy feed. This could be a great help in order to improve her sources of income. This will produce more chickens to be sold. In this way, she would be able to provide her children with a nutritious diet.

She hopes that she could expand her layer farm to be become sustainable and successful in the near future.

loans.use: to buy feed

loans.name: Jessica

texts.en:
Jessica is a hardworking and persevering mother, who is always known to provide her family the best. Jessica wants all her children to earn a degree and become successful in their chosen fields. 

With the loan of Php5,000, she will be able to pay for the school tuition of her daughter. 

She deeply wishes to live a happy and healthy life with her children having stable jobs.

loans.use: to pay for the school tuition of her daughter

loans.name: Arlyn

texts.en:
Arlyn is 48 years old and lives in Rizal, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. He is single with no dependents.

Arlyn earns his living from sales at his own convenience store, an eatery and a refreshment shop business. He's been in these businesses for 15 years already and earns approximately PHP 30,000 each month doing this type of work; this amount is very helpful in meeting his needs. He is a good citizen and presently serving his constituents as a member of the Barangay Council in his community. 

He has requested a loan to be used in purchasing an additional stock of groceries and consumable products for his existing grocery store and refreshment shop. 

Arlyn has been a member of PMPC for almost two years. In the future, he hopes to renovate and expand his grocery and refreshment shop.

loans.use: To purchase an additional stock of groceries and consumable products

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria runs a sari-sari (variety) store. She sells basic commodities like sugar, powdered milk, noodles, bread, chips, candies, canned goods, soft drinks and toiletries. In addition to that, she also goes fishing as additional source of income. She is a 46-year-old  married woman with six children. Three of them are still attending school. 

She has requested a loan to purchase stock like canned goods, soap and shampoo. 

This will help improve the variety of goods, as well as attract more buyers to shop and purchase. Her income will augmented. She would now start to balance her finances, and able to settle her obligations. She would now able to continue sending her children to school and provide them with healthy diets.

She hopes that she could expand her business and able to set aside more capital for the success of her livelihood.

loans.use: to purchase stock like canned goods, soap and shampoo

loans.name: Samson

texts.en:
Samson is 60 years old, married, and blessed with eight children. He has been a dairy farmer for the last 12 years and it has been profitable. 

He has applied for his first loan of KES 25,000 from Vision Fund Kenya to buy a dairy cow to enable him to increase the amount of milk he supplies to his customers and thereby to earn more income to educate his children.

In future, he hopes to improve his farming business and be able to support his family.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow to enable him to increase the amount of milk he supplies to his customers and thereby to earn more income to educate his children.

loans.name: Geraldine

texts.en:
Geraldine is married and the mother of two children. 

She engaged in a transport business, and recently took out a loan from GDMPC micro credit to pay for motorcycle registration so that her motorcycle can continue do the service and cater more passengers. She will also use a portion of this loan for vehicle repairs and maintenance.  

She hopes someday that she can buy a new motorcycle to expand her business.

loans.use: to pay for motorcycle registration.

loans.name: Absolom

texts.en:
Absolom is 34 years old, married to Ruth and they are blessed with 3 children. He has been a small-scale farmer for the last 10 years and it has been profitable. He grows maize, sugarcane and he is also a dairy farmer.

He will use the loan to buy a dairy cow to enable him to increase the amount of milk supplied to his customers and get more income to educate his children.

His future hopes are to grow his farming, make more income and be able to support his family.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow to enable him to increase the amount of milk supplied to his customers and get more income to support his family
